descriptionProfile: Photographer, Co-founder Witness Change, Human Rights Activist, Supports LGBT rights, No Health Without Mental Health, Love animals so I don't eat em!
Photographer, Co-founder Witness Change, Human Rights Activist, Supports LGBT rights, No Health Without Mental Health, Love animals so I don't eat em!

posts.description:
Documenting human rights abuses for @witness_change I came across this young man shackled to the floor of Juba Central Prison in South Sudan. His only crime was to have a mental disability. I made a promise to myself that I would do something for the thousands of people like him in countries with insufficient resources to effectively care for people with mental health issues. 
In many countries around the world, the people I spoke to said there was still so much stigma around mental health. I hope you will join me in fighting stigma and creating a better world for people who need mental health support. 
1 in 4 people around the world, experiences a mental disorder or psychosocial disability in their lifetime. 
In some countries, 98% of people with mental illness and intellectually disability receive no treatment

Find out more at 
https://witnesschange.org/condemned/

#worldhealthday #worldhealthday2017 #letstalk #mentalhealth #stopstigma

Photo @Hammond_Robin / @noorimages for @natgeo. Eriah Big Crow at Red Cloud School on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota, USA. Eriah wants to be a doctor when she grows up so she can "make people in Pine Ridge better." Eriah is one of the many 9 year olds I had the privilege of photographing and interviewing for the National Geographic January 2017 special issue #GenderRevolution. While plenty of the kids made it into the digital and magazine edition, Eriah sadly didn’t - just too many great kids to choose from. There are plenty of other amazing children from around the world speaking their minds in the magazine and online version though. If you’re interested in seeing other outtakes, I’m sharing them on my account: @Hammond_Robin

Photo @Hammond_Robin / @noorimages for @natgeo. Yingzhi Wang at home in Beijing, China. He says that the worst thing about boys is that they bully girls, who are timid and weak. They should be more like his Dad he says, who protects his family. Yingzhi is one of the many 9 year olds I had the privilege of photographing and interviewing for the National Geographic January 2017 special issue #GenderRevolution. He appears in the magazine, but with a different picture. If you’re interested in seeing other outtakes, I’ll be sharing them in the coming days on my account: @Hammond_Robin

Photo @Hammond_Robin / @noorimages for @natgeo. Lokamu Lopulmoe, at the temporary village settlement of her family in #Turkana, # Kenya. She is one of the many 9 year olds I had the privilege of photographing and interviewing for the National Geographic January 2017 special issue #GenderRevolution. While plenty of the kids made it into the digital and magazine edition, Lokamu sadly didn’t - just too many great kids to choose from. There are plenty of other amazing children from around the world speaking their minds in the magazine and online version though. If you’re interested in seeing other outtakes, I’ll be sharing them in the coming days on my account: @Hammond_Robin

Photo @Hammond_Robin / @noorimages for @natgeo. Ibrahim Alnajjar at home in Khan Younis, Gaza, Palestine. Ibrahim’s house was destroyed during the war of 2014. He now lives in a ‘caravan’ and complains of bitter cold in winter and unbearable heat during the summer months. Ibrahim is one of the many 9 year olds I had the privilege of photographing and interviewing for the National Geographic January 2017 special issue #GenderRevolution. He appears in the magazine, but with a different picture. If you’re interested in seeing other outtakes, I’ll be sharing them in the coming days on my account: @Hammond_Robin

Photo @Hammond_Robin / @noorimages for @natgeo. Lais Machado Dos Santos at home in #Rio de Janeiro. Lais is dressed in her Mangueira Children’s #Samba School dance costume. She is one of the many 9 year olds I had the privilege of photographing and interviewing for the National Geographic January 2017 special issue #GenderRevolution. While plenty of the kids made it into the digital and magazine edition, Lais sadly didn’t - just too many great kids to choose from. There are plenty of other amazing children from around the world speaking their minds in the magazine and online version though. If you’re interested in seeing other outtakes, I’ll be sharing them in the coming days on my account: @Hammond_Robin

Photo @Hammond_Robin for @natgeo. William, from #Canada, wants to be “computer genius” when he grows up. He is one of the many 9 year olds I had the privilege of photographing and interviewing for the National Geographic special January 2017 issue on Gender. While plenty of the kids made it into the digital and magazine edition, William sadly didn’t (but he did make the video). Lots of other great children from around the world speaking their minds in the magazine and online version. #GenderRevolution. If you’re interested in seeing other outtakes, I’ll be sharing here in the coming days: @Hammond_Robin

Photo @hammond_robin / @noorimages for @natgeo “The best thing about being a girl is, now I don’t have to pretend to be a boy” says Avery Jackson who I photographed for #NationalGeographic's special issue on Gender. #GenderRevolution
Getting ready to present @whereloveisillegal at @natgeo tonight in Washington DC
